text: Is there any way to get/set the country ISO code automatically with a workflow? Should be pretty easily done by a custom code?
Could be offloaded to a serverless function if you have those available. So the CCA would just send the XML to the serverless endpoint, and receive JSON back for further processing.

Yep, it would be pretty easy with custom code, you could just build out a table of this data or connect to one of the many apis <https://public.opendatasoft.com/explore/dataset/countries-codes/table/>
Thanks Carter, need to have a look on this. Its a bit weird that this is not a standard field.
Yeah I could definitely be on board with making it a standard field
Here's where me and BJ go through it <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/archives/C2YHAHB6K/p1669434949126989>

So with API keys sunsetting tomorrow, I’m wanting to do one final check and make sure there are no api keys in my workflows. I dont think there is, but wanted to double check with you guys on if you have found a better way, but there is no way to search all workflows for your api key, right?
HubSpot checks if an active Key is detected or not. If it is detected you get a red notification at the top when logging in
I got the red banner, but I havent been able to see what workflow has it. I thought I got them all, but must be missing one!

Hey Team - New here so please let me know if someone else has covered this before. I have a Custom Code workflow to change two letter country codes to the full names and copy it into the Country/Region open text field on the Contact record. It works most of the time but the other 90% it throws a “Unable to update property” Error. I can find a pattern or reason as to why. Has anyone else had this issue? or any ideas on how to fix it? Happy to share the code/workflow information as necessary.
Do you have an example of one of the values that isnt able to copy?
Now are you outputting the property and then updating it with the set property value action or just setting it with the custom code?
Yeah, but there's a limitation to that - URL's can only have x amount of characters, plus you need to regex any #. It's just a poor way of doing it (not to mention costs)
